hints.content:
Every coin has a different value.

Coin name | Picture | Value
- | - | -
Penny | ![Front and back photo of penny.](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/d0799f515398b1f48cb0baa7bdc8d0c12e26c70c.png) | $1¢$
Nickel | ![Front and back photo of nickel.](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/f6c7ae82228012be92b624995809aeabc8e95370.png) | $5¢$
Dime | ![Front and back photo of dime.](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/2017369b968caa0c88d046bddf2406665c8cd34d.png) | $10¢$
Quarter | ![Front and back photo of quarter.](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/1cc5cb6f4c779c49984f5a63a58443ce0ca96ff9.png) | $25¢$

Let's label the value of each set of coins and find the total.

![2, quarters. 3, nickels. 4, pennies.](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/1dce86373c56d73ff518c634ffe484e77dcbdbc6.png)

$\begin{align}
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢} + \blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{2}{\text{ quarters}}} + \underbrace{\goldE{5¢} +\goldE{5¢} + \goldE{5¢}}_{\goldE{3}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{1¢} +\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}+\maroonD{1¢} }_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}\\\\
&\underbrace{\blueE{50¢}}_{\blueE{2}{\text{ quarters}}}  +  \underbrace{\goldE{15¢}}_{\goldE{3}{\text{ nickels}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{4¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}=69¢
\end{align}$

This set of coins has a value of $69¢$, so it is **not** equal to $59¢$.

![2, quarters. 1, dime. 4, pennies.](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/8bcffd095215821cf053750fdf303dec98ac5456.png)

$\begin{align}
&\underbrace{\blueE{25¢} + \blueE{25¢}}_{\blueE{2}{\text{ quarters}}}  + \underbrace{\purpleD{10¢}}_{\purpleD{1}{\text{ dime}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{1¢} +\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}+\maroonD{1¢} }_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}\\\\
&\underbrace{\blueE{50¢}}_{\blueE{2}{\text{ quarters}}}  +  \underbrace{\purpleD{10¢}}_{\purpleD{1}{\text{ dime}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{4¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}=64¢
\end{align}$

This set of coins has a value of $64¢$, so it is **not** equal to $59¢$.

![5, dimes. 1, nickel. 4, pennies.](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/57358f030969531bdbcc82b825b8ef56f0ef58b3.png)

$\begin{align}
&\underbrace{\purpleD{10¢} + \purpleD{10¢}+ \purpleD{10¢} + \purpleD{10¢} + \purpleD{10¢}}_{\purpleD{5}{\text{ dimes}}} + \underbrace{\goldE{5¢}}_{\goldE{1}{\text{ nickel}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢} +\maroonD{1¢} + \maroonD{1¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}\\\\
&\underbrace{\purpleD{50¢}}_{\purpleD{5}{\text{ dimes}}} + \underbrace{\goldE{5¢}}_{\goldE{1}{\text{ nickel}}} +\underbrace{\maroonD{4¢}}_{\maroonD{4}{\text{ pennies}}}=59¢
\end{align}$

This set of coins has a value of $59¢$, so it **is** equal to Tirzah's amount of money.

Tirzah could have this set of coins:

![5, dimes. 1, nickel. 4, pennies.](https://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-images/57358f030969531bdbcc82b825b8ef56f0ef58b3.png)

question.content:
Tirzah has $59¢$.

**Which set of coins could Tirzah have?**

[[☃ radio 1]]
